facts.fact_text: Silver slid as much as 9.6% to below $64.1 per ounce on Friday.

evidences.evidence_text: Silver slid as much as 9.6% to below $64.1 per ounce on Friday, sinking to its lowest level in seven weeks amid widespread deleveraging and a deepening selloff across financial markets.

facts.fact_text: Silver is down roughly 45% from its Jan. 29 peak.

evidences.evidence_text: The white metal is now down roughly 45% from its Jan. 29 peak, wiping out all gains for the year and marking its steepest collapse since 1980.

facts.fact_text: Silver's collapse is the steepest since 1980.

evidences.evidence_text: The white metal is now down roughly 45% from its Jan. 29 peak, wiping out all gains for the year and marking its steepest collapse since 1980.

claims.claim_text: Speculative buying, particularly from Chinese traders, added froth to the rally, leaving prices vulnerable to a sharp reversal as sentiment turned.

evidences.evidence_text: Speculative buying, particularly from Chinese traders, added froth to the rally, leaving prices vulnerable to a sharp reversal as sentiment turned.

claims.claim_text: Pressure on precious metals increased further after a sharp rebound in the dollar following the nomination of Kevin Warsh as the next Fed chair, widely seen as the more hawkish choice.

evidences.evidence_text: Pressure on precious metals increased further after a sharp rebound in the dollar following the nomination of Kevin Warsh as the next Fed chair, widely seen as the more hawkish choice.

claims.claim_text: Silver's volatility outpaced other metals as heavy speculative flows overshadowed its supply-demand fundamentals.

evidences.evidence_text: Silver’s volatility outpaced other metals as heavy speculative flows overshadowed its supply-demand fundamentals.

evidence.evidence_text: Silver and other precious metals had surged to record highs in January, driven by heightened geopolitical risks, economic uncertainty, and concerns over the US Federal Reserve’s independence that fueled safe-haven demand.

Silver and other precious metals had surged to record highs in January, driven by heightened geopolitical risks, economic uncertainty, and concerns over the US Federal Reserve’s independence that fueled safe-haven demand.
